text: So putting myself in the shoes of those particular companies, like I said, I think some of my most rewarding interactions have been with these non Silicon Valley companies. I certainly learn a lot when I talk to companies in the Bay Area and in the United States to do those particular things.
speaker: John Cutler
context: Lenny asks John about the differences between Silicon Valley product teams and companies going through digital transformations. John explains that much of the advice available online is geared toward Silicon Valley startups, but most product managers work at companies that don't fit that mold. He shares that some of his most rewarding work has been with non-Silicon Valley companies that are trying to transform their approach to building products.
vocabulary_highlights: putting myself in the shoes of
text_ko: 제가 그 회사들 입장이 돼서 생각해 보면, 말씀드렸듯이 가장 보람 있었던 만남 중 일부는 실리콘밸리 밖에 있는 회사들과의 교류였어요. 물론 베이 에어리어(Bay Area)나 미국에 있는 그런 회사들과 얘기할 때도 많은 걸 배워요.
text_zh: 所以站在那些公司的角度来看，就像我刚才说的，我觉得跟这些非硅谷公司打交道是最有收获的。当然了，跟湾区和美国其他地方的公司聊天，我也学到很多东西。
text_es: Entonces, poniéndome en el lugar de esas empresas en particular, como te decía, creo que algunas de mis interacciones más gratificantes han sido con estas empresas que no son del Silicon Valley. Definitivamente aprendo muchísimo cuando hablo con empresas de la Bahía de San Francisco y de Estados Unidos para hacer esas cosas específicas.

text: Part of the thing is just realizing how much inertia they're up against when you're chatting them. So I do believe that there's some structural things that probably they could avoid, but then there's also just structural things that are just part of the game to do that.
speaker: John Cutler
context: John continues discussing the challenges faced by larger enterprise companies trying to adopt modern product practices. He explains that these companies face significant organizational inertia - resistance to change built into their existing structures and processes. Some structural barriers can be overcome, while others are simply inherent to operating at that scale and in those industries.
text_ko: 일부는 그들과 얘기할 때 그들이 얼마나 큰 관성(inertia)에 맞서고 있는지를 깨닫는 것뿐이에요. 그래서 피할 수 있는 구조적 문제들(structural)이 분명히 있다고 생각해요. 하지만 어쩔 수 없이 그 과정의 일부로 존재하는 구조적 요소들도 있어요.
text_zh: 其实很大一部分原因就是，你跟他们聊的时候会发现，他们面临的阻力有多大。所以我觉得有些结构性的问题他们可能是能避免的，但还有一些结构性的问题就是游戏规则的一部分，没办法。
text_es: Parte del asunto es darse cuenta de cuánta inercia tienen en contra cuando estás hablando con ellos. Así que sí creo que hay algunas cosas estructurales que probablemente podrían evitar, pero también hay cosas estructurales que simplemente son parte del juego para hacer eso.

text: So I think that for a lot of those companies, they see adopting the frameworks as the end goal. They kind of look there. And sometimes maybe even you write a post, it's like, 'Well, how does Figma work?' And they're like, 'We use these frameworks.'
speaker: John Cutler
context: John discusses a common mistake that transforming companies make when trying to adopt modern product practices. Instead of understanding the principles behind successful product development, these companies focus on copying the specific frameworks and tools used by successful companies like Figma. John argues this approach misses the point - frameworks should be learning tools, not end goals in themselves.
text_ko: 저는 많은 회사들이 프레임워크(frameworks)를 도입하는 걸 그 자체 목표로 보는 것 같아요. 그래서 거기에만 초점을 맞추는 편이고요. 가끔 글을 써서 'Figma가 어떻게 작동하나요?'라고 물어봐도, '우린 이런 프레임워크만 써요'라고만 답하더라고요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得很多公司都把采用这些框架当成最终目标了。他们就盯着这个看。有时候你可能写个帖子问"Figma是怎么运作的？"他们就回答说"我们用这些框架。"
text_es: Entonces creo que muchas de esas empresas ven adoptar los marcos de trabajo (frameworks) como el objetivo final. Como que se enfocan en eso. Y a veces hasta escribes un post preguntando "¿Cómo funciona Figma?" y te responden "Nosotros usamos estos frameworks."

text: And so I think that the way that I tend to think about frameworks is that they're more like a job aid. They're more like a learning tool that the team kind of uses to keep themself on track. But part of the thing is that those companies will reinvent the things they're using when things aren't working out.
speaker: John Cutler
context: John explains his philosophy on how frameworks should be used in product development. Rather than treating frameworks as rigid processes that must be followed exactly, he views them as job aids - tools that help teams learn and stay focused. Successful companies adapt and modify frameworks when they're not working, rather than blindly following them regardless of results.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 프레임워크(frameworks)를 오히려 업무 보조 도구(job aid)처럼 보는 편이에요. 팀이 스스로 길을 잃지 않게 도와주는 학습 도구 같은 거고요. 다만 잘 안 풀리면 그런 회사들은 쓰고 있던 것들을 다시 만들어 버리기도 해요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得吧，框架(framework)这个东西更像是一个工作辅助工具。就是团队用来让自己不跑偏的学习工具。但关键是，如果现有的东西不好用了，那些公司会重新发明他们在用的工具。
text_es: Y entonces, yo creo que la forma en que suelo ver los frameworks es más como una herramienta de apoyo en el trabajo. Son más como una herramienta de aprendizaje que el equipo usa para mantenerse enfocado. Pero lo que pasa es que esas empresas van a reinventar las cosas que están usando cuando no les están funcionando.

text: And I talk about this a lot, this sort of I do believe there's sort of this fundamental attribution bias at play where people in these high performings don't acknowledge the amount that luck and inertia has been a part of what they're doing.
speaker: John Cutler
context: Lenny and John are discussing why advice from successful Silicon Valley companies doesn't always work for other organizations. John explains that there's a cognitive bias where successful companies and leaders attribute their success primarily to their skills and decisions, while underestimating the role of luck, timing, and favorable circumstances. This leads to advice that may not be applicable to companies in different situations.
text_ko: 저는 이 얘기를 자주 하는데, 일종의 근본적 귀인 편향(fundamental attribution bias)이 있어서 성과가 높은 사람들일수록 자신들이 해온 일에 운과 관성이 얼마나 기여했는지를 잘 인정하지 않는다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我经常说这个问题，我觉得这里面有个根本归因偏误(fundamental attribution bias)在起作用，就是那些业绩特别好的人，他们不愿意承认运气和惯性在他们成功中占了多大分量。
text_es: Y hablo mucho de esto, creo que hay como un sesgo de atribución fundamental (fundamental attribution bias) en juego donde la gente que tiene mucho éxito no reconoce hasta qué punto la suerte y la inercia han sido parte de lo que han logrado.

text: And that the people in the big companies, or these not, these companies that believe that it's not the way that they can do that actually overestimate the kind of systemic drag in their organization and underestimate what can be possible.
speaker: John Cutler
context: John continues explaining the attribution bias that affects how companies view their ability to change. While successful companies underestimate the role of luck in their success, struggling companies tend to overestimate the barriers holding them back (systemic drag) and underestimate what improvements are actually possible within their constraints.
text_ko: 대기업에 있는 사람들이나 '그건 우리가 못 해'라고 믿는 회사들은 조직의 시스템적 저항(systemic drag)을 과대평가하고 실제로 가능한 것들은 과소평가해요.
text_zh: 那些大公司的人，或者说那些认为这样做不可行的公司，其实都高估了自己组织内部的体系阻力(systemic drag)，低估了真正能做到的事情。
text_es: Y la gente de las empresas grandes, o bueno, estas empresas que creen que no es la forma en que pueden hacerlo, en realidad sobreestiman la inercia del sistema (systemic drag) que tienen en su organización y subestiman lo que realmente se puede lograr.

text: I think that what I realized over the course of these four years is that I wanted to pivot back to help put most of my energy into helping my own company. They're growing super fast, so the numbers are in the hundreds of everything or in the thousands of everything.
speaker: John Cutler
context: John explains why he's leaving his role as Product Evangelist at Amplitude to join Toast. After four years of helping hundreds of different companies improve their product practices, he wants to focus his energy on helping one company - Toast - which is experiencing rapid growth and has multiple business lines beyond just their core point-of-sale business.
text_ko: 이 4년 동안 깨달은 건 제가 다시 제 회사 쪽으로 방향을 틀어(pivot back) 제 에너지 대부분을 그쪽에 쏟고 싶었다는 거예요. 회사가 엄청 빨리 커지고 있어서 거의 모든 수치가 수백 단위거나 많게는 수천 단위예요.
text_zh: 我觉得这四年下来我意识到，我想要转回去(pivot)，把大部分精力都投入到帮助自己的公司上。他们现在发展特别快，各项数据都是几百几千这个量级的。
text_es: Creo que lo que me di cuenta durante estos cuatro años es que quería cambiar de rumbo y enfocar la mayor parte de mi energía en ayudar a mi propia empresa. Están creciendo súper rápido, así que las cifras están en cientos de todo o en miles de todo.
